Sunday: `Connected' and the SpaceX Landing

\hypertarget{whats-on-tv-sunday-connected-and-the-spacex-landing}{%
\section{What's on TV Sunday: `Connected' and the SpaceX
Landing}\label{whats-on-tv-sunday-connected-and-the-spacex-landing}}

``Radiolab'' journalist Latif Nasser hosts a new show on Netflix, and
the SpaceX craft makes its return to Earth.

\includegraphics{https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/08/02/arts/02tvcol-connected/02tvcol-connected-articleLarge.jpg?quality=75\&auto=webp\&disable=upscale}

By Lauren Messman

\begin{itemize}
\item
  Aug. 2, 2020, 1:00 a.m. ET
\item
  \begin{itemize}
  \item
  \item
  \item
  \item
  \item
  \end{itemize}
\end{itemize}

\hypertarget{whats-streaming}{%
\subsection{What's Streaming}\label{whats-streaming}}

\textbf{CONNECTED} \emph{Stream on}
\href{https://www.netflix.com/search?q=connected\&jbv=81031737}{\emph{Netflix.}}
** As the
\href{https://www.wnycstudios.org/people/latif-nasser}{director of
research} for
\href{https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/10/magazine/mag-10Radiolab-t.html?searchResultPosition=3}{``Radiolab,''}
Latif Nasser has covered all sorts of fascinating stories for the
science podcast, like that of a Guantánamo
Bay\href{https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/03/arts/radiolab-the-other-latif-guantanamo.html}{detainee
who shares his name}, or what the 2016
\href{https://www.wnycstudios.org/podcasts/radiolab/articles/radiolab-punchline}{N.H.L.
All-Star Game can teach us about democracy.} Now, as the host of this
new Netflix show, Nasser will uncover the surprising ways humans are
connected to one another, the world and the universe at large. It's a
fascinating topic --- one that highlights how a law of numerical
probability applies to classical music, social media and tax fraud, or
how a shipwreck laid the ground work for weather forecasting and cloud
computing.

\hypertarget{whats-on-tv}{%
\subsection{What's on TV}\label{whats-on-tv}}

\includegraphics{https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/08/02/arts/02tvcol-spacex2/02tvcol-spacex2-articleLarge.jpg?quality=75\&auto=webp\&disable=upscale}

\textbf{SPACE LAUNCH LIVE: SPLASHDOWN} \emph{1 p.m. on Discovery and
Science Channel.} Back in May,
\href{https://deadline.com/2020/06/space-launch-live-america-returns-to-space-discovery-science-channel-tv-ratings-spacex-1202951359/}{millions
of people} turned their eyes to the skies (and their screens) to witness
the
\href{https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/30/science/spacex-nasa-astronauts.html}{launch
of the SpaceX Crew Dragon spacecraft}. The mission, which was a
partnership between NASA and Elon Musk's company SpaceX, marked the
first time U.S. astronauts were sent into orbit onboard a private
spacecraft. Now, after spending two months docked at the International
Space Station, the astronauts, Robert L. Behnken and Douglas O. Hurley,
will make their journey home. The host Chris Jacobs will be joined by
current and former astronauts, engineers and other special guests,
before the spacecraft's scheduled landing in the Atlantic Ocean.

\textbf{HIROSHIMA: 75 YEARS LATER} \emph{9 p.m. on History.} This
two-hour documentary looks back at the development, detonation and
aftermath of the atomic bombing of Hiroshima, Japan, featuring the
perspectives of leaders, physicists, soldiers and survivors who
witnessed its catastrophic destruction. Featuring archival footage,
color film from the aftermath and audio testimony from victims, the film
takes a hard look at one of the most devastating moments in human
history through a moral and scientific lens.

Image

Greg Davies, left, and Alex Horne in ``Taskmaster.''Credit...Avalon UKTV

\textbf{TASKMASTER} \emph{9 p.m. on the CW.} This widely entertaining
series assigns a group of comedians with a number of creatively vague
tasks --- such as ``make the most exotic sandwich'' or ``fill an egg cup
with tears" --- leaving the host, Greg Davies, and the task devisor,
Alex Horne, to choose a winner. It's a clever take on the
\href{https://www.vulture.com/2011/07/a-guide-to-the-hilarious-world-of-british-panel-shows.html\#access_token=eyJhbGciOiJSUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCIsImtpZCI6Ik1FSXlNVFZETTBaQlEwUTJSVUV6UkVVMlFqWTNNRU13TVRaR09UWTFNVE0yUTBZeE16RXpOQSJ9..lVcYhtBnryCtudwiAEomYl6uof5SiOcpcf3ypGglZ_O-evRonBTgIsuojN_TZDC0kMkj7N2mYFBlS1HOPwQ1hTUZEMvxmp6Wk-fbwhb8iqipt6-TheeEGqn_YnlFarv6hadkGhRXPFXolMBFoUTqQmMGMdLt3ghiNI6Q-hpXPICLILprH4UgOzrkYbStMOZiVUIFPC58FBRttbvZwFbi1qTE1vxO8oVPClsiB0vqbL9ophy35PFZB2PumkWmfCJDEV1kuTk5L8-E-fX3_8S9GxH4NaQT8pjXFpaWjoje16gTTa9XqJqajGdSlC-YQC0xYE2jMm2Ly0rkRPyLVhOLuw\&scope=openid\%20profile\%20email\%20read\%3Acurrent_user\%20update\%3Acurrent_user_metadata\&expires_in=7200\&token_type=Bearer\&state=OPAQUE_VALUE\&id_token=eyJhbGciOiJSUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCIsImtpZCI6Ik1FSXlNVFZETTBaQlEwUTJSVUV6UkVVMlFqWTNNRU13TVRaR09UWTFNVE0yUTBZeE16RXpOQSJ9._.acEkSBWUO1rx3HqFzFDwqpje7SDnUCsHLbn-xKZLgrmR3DZ2_wVlgHBQ2ry2un9ac4oxtE0EKB9uTHrBOphc9lwRMIKRRRCHQy_ESjjl0oYBKefeEforqvS37FTMsdIJyFJo2e3blJf05Q8XEdywYkS4lOifUlLPzZ0WLVOXVjkQQjaYSA7yYpuGPGqY29fkaOrETDolWRkkn2EvX482EVnSxXdwAx5WAIEbo1LBUTxS2pJcjLVD4v_yh2nDY1bU1oFaB-2tcobMLmykNEz2-6nXoS8OkscgNIRvmQCGtwyuvaUzIpATkF5KkO7l7LRDgLngT4Cu1loq-fLYfyDQBw}{classic
British panel show format} that doubles as a devious way to torture its
celebrity guests --- with
\href{https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J0jiSqHrLHM}{hilarious, and
occasionally genius, results.}

\textbf{I'LL BE GONE IN THE DARK} \emph{10 p.m. on HBO.} In April 2018,
the decades-long search for the sexual predator known as the Golden
State Killer, concluded in
\href{https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/25/us/golden-state-killer-serial.html}{the
arrest of Joseph James DeAngelo.} But the true crime writer
\href{https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/25/books/michelle-mcnamara-patton-oswalt.html}{Michelle
McNamara}, who spent years investigating the case, died before she could
see the man who terrorized California in the 1970s and '80s brought to
justice. This
\href{https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/25/arts/television/ill-be-gone-in-the-dark-review-michelle-mcnamara.html}{six-part
series} traces the evolution of the case, as well as McNamara's
remarkable life and work, as an adaptation
of\href{https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/25/books/michelle-mcnamara-patton-oswalt.html}{her
book}, which was
\href{https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/15/books/michelle-mcnamara-patton-oswalt-book-serial-killer.html}{published}posthumously.
In the finale, McNamara's husband, the comedian Patton Oswalt, connects
with survivors of DeAngelo's crimes and reflects on McNamara's absence.
